description: {"blocks":[{"key":"6uvf1","text":"This protocol describes the method used at Colorado State University to extract and quantify SARS-CoV-2 in wastewater collected from sewers and at wastewater treatment plants.  The method relies on concentration via ultrafiltration, silica column based purification, and quantification via digital droplet reverse transcription PCR.  Endogenous and exogenous controls are described.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

WWTPs tend to have a characteristic level of F+ and PMMoV which depends on the flow rate, population served etc.  ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":1,"offset":21,"style":"sup"},{"length":2,"offset":25,"style":"sup"}],"key":"2h4if","text":"PMMoV falls in the 108-109 copies per L range.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":1,"offset":40,"style":"sup"},{"length":2,"offset":44,"style":"sup"}],"key":"8sha9","text":"F+ coliphage is less abundant, in the 107-108 copies per L range.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"1":{"type":"tex_formula","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"formula":"Genomes/L = C(R_{T}/R_{U}) (1000/W)(I_{P}/I_{E})*100","guid":"E0F0F0ECAAF611EC9B530A58A9FEAC02","id":0}},"2":{"type":"tex_formula","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"formula":"Genomes/L = 130.66  C * I_{P}","guid":"E0F0F182AAF611EC9B530A58A9FEAC02","id":0}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"3d9f0","text":"Quality Controls and Troubleshooting","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":36}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"79pa8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9jk0u","text":"One possible use of the controls is for normalization.  In our experience with Colorado WWTPs normalization to either exogenous (BCoV) or endogenous controls (PMMoV, F+) did not improve correlations with community infection rate or reduce variability.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"emov8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f9f2b","text":"The controls can also be used to detect failure of reactions due to inhibitors and to distinguish between inhibition and degradation:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"boqrk","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4lbve","text":"Both the reverse transcription step and the PCR step can be inhibited by compounds that carry through the extraction step (either reagents such as phenol or guanidine, or contaminants such as humic acids).  Inhibition of the RT step will generally result in fewer positive droplets (because there will be less cDNA produced) and confounds accurate quantification.  Inhibition of the PCR step can result in reduced fluorescence amplitude i.e. poor separation of the positive and negative droplets, because each cycle will produce fewer copies of the cDNA template).  This may not affect quantification if the separation remains adequate for threshold setting.   Inhibition is not template specific - all targets in a reaction mix will be affected. Low BCoV recovery (\u003c5%) can indicate inhibition of the RT step.  Importantly, inhibition can often be abrogated by using less of the RNA containing the inhibitor.  Therefore the PMMoV/F+ reaction will generally give good results even when inhibitors are present because it uses a 100 fold diluted RNA template.  If BCoV recovery fails QC, it is helpful to rerun the reaction with half or quarter the amount of RNA template (assuming the SARS-N1 levels are high enough to still be detected).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6tqdg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3sp76","text":"In contrast, degradation of the RNA sample will result in fewer positive droplets for all four targets (i.e. Low BCOV recovery and low PMMoV/F+).  This problem can only be remedied by repeating the extraction to make fresh RNA.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"91ctm","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"933g","text":"RNA quality cannot be easily evaluated prior to the ddPCR assay because even good quality RNA is generally very low abundance (too low for nanodrop), partially degraded and represents a mixture of nucleic acids from a variety of microbes, viruses and human cells (confounds Tapestation/Bioanalyzer).  Fluorescent measurements (such as Qubit) may be informative but add time and expense.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e1hum","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"as2e7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"46b2f","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
